messageBody:
Thanks for the feedback J.B.

I understand your position on the usage of "developer testing", but
we did not coin or introduce the term. I agree with you that there
are too many terms that mean similar things, but "developer testing"
is what most people and companies out there seem to use to describe
the act of software developers getting seriously involved in test
development. Even in the Agile community, people like Brian Marick
(one of the original authors of the Agile Manifesto) use "developer
testing".

Right or wrong, most people interpret "programmer testing" as the
testing *of* a programmer's skill (e.g. certification.)

There is also the issue that some "software engineers" want to be
though of as developers and not programmers. What's the difference
between a programmer and a developer? I haven't seen a serious
definition of the two, but below is a humorous attempt I read
somewhere (origins unknown):

* Programmer: A biological machine designed to convert caffeine into
code.

* Developer: A person who develops working systems by writing and
using software.

Using this definition, I guess all of us are sometimes programmers
and sometimes developers :-). Although, apparently, you can't be a
programmer if you drink decaf.

In general usage I hear and read "unit testing", "developer
testing", and "programmer testing" used quite interchangeably (and
in that order of frequency).

>(What's a "unit" anyway?)

That's another challenge altogether :-), but that's the primary
reason why I thought that "developer testing" was better than "unit
testing."

Alberto
